title_en: Traces of Flowers and the Moon
description: A major scholar-and-beauty romance of the late Qing, interweaving love stories with the Taiping Rebellion. Known for its lyrical poetry and depiction of courtesans and failed scholars.

title_en: Romance of the Sui and Tang Dynasties
description: The great historical novel of the Sui-Tang transition, covering the fall of the Sui dynasty through the rise of the Tang. Features famous characters like Li Shimin, Qin Shubao, and Cheng Yaojin.

title_en: Dream Memories of Tao'an
description: The finest collection of nostalgic essays in Chinese literature. Zhang Dai, a ruined Ming aristocrat, recalls the vanished world of late Ming Jiangnan: opera, tea, lantern festivals, lake excursions.

title_en: Random Thoughts on Idle Pleasures
description: The most comprehensive manual of aesthetics and daily life in Chinese literature. Covers drama, music, costume, gardening, food, architecture, and health with wit and opinion.

title_en: Expanded Records of the Forest of Laughter
description: The largest and most famous Chinese joke collection. Hundreds of jokes organized by category: stupid people, ridiculous officials, stingy men, marital humor, and more.

title_en: Random Notes on Poetry from the Sui Garden
description: The most entertaining collection of poetry criticism in Chinese. Yuan Mei combines anecdotes, critical judgments, and hundreds of quoted poems, championing spirit and feeling over formalism.

title_en: Grades of Poetry
description: The earliest systematic ranking and critical evaluation of Chinese poets. Zhong Rong grades 122 poets from Han to his own day into three tiers with critical comments on each.

title_en: Comments of a Recluse
description: A penetrating social critique of Eastern Han dynasty corruption, nepotism, and moral decay. Wang Fu writes from outside the establishment with sharp observations on governance and human nature.

title_en: Random Notes from the Rongzhai Studio
description: The most scholarly and wide-ranging biji collection of the Song dynasty. Covers history, literature, philology, politics, and daily life with extraordinary erudition across 1,230 entries.

title_en: Records of Learning Difficulties
description: One of the greatest works of evidential scholarship in Chinese history. Wang Yinglin meticulously investigates textual problems across the classics, histories, and philosophy.

title_en: Miscellaneous Morsels from Youyang
description: The most fascinating and eclectic biji collection of the Tang dynasty. Covers natural history, folklore, foreign lands, Buddhist and Daoist lore, food, drugs, ghosts, and oddities. Contains the earliest known Chinese Cinderella story.

title_en: Notes from the Old Scholar's Studio
description: Personal notes by one of the greatest Song poets. Lu You records anecdotes about politics, literature, customs, and daily life in the Southern Song, full of eyewitness accounts of the Jurchen wars.

title_en: Dreams of Splendor of the Eastern Capital
description: The most detailed account of urban life in the Northern Song capital Kaifeng before its fall to the Jurchen in 1127. Markets, restaurants, festivals, entertainment, and daily customs described with nostalgic precision.

title_en: Random Talks North of the Pond
description: A major biji collection by the leading poet-critic of the early Qing. Covers literature, history, supernatural tales, and contemporary events across four thematic sections.

title_en: Commentary on the Waterways Classic
description: The greatest geographical text of pre-modern China. Li Daoyuan expanded a terse river catalog into a richly detailed account of landscapes, cities, legends, and inscriptions along China's waterways.

title_en: Essential Techniques for the Common People
description: The oldest and most comprehensive agricultural manual surviving from China. Covers crop cultivation, animal husbandry, food processing, brewing, and fermentation.

title_en: A Book to Burn
description: The most iconoclastic work of the late Ming. Li Zhi attacked Confucian hypocrisy, championed individual moral autonomy, and defended vernacular fiction and women's intellectual capacity.

title_en: Records of Ming Scholars
description: The first systematic history of philosophy in any language. Huang Zongxi traces the development of Confucian thought through the entire Ming dynasty, school by school.

title_en: Random Jottings at the Cottage of Close Scrutiny
description: The greatest collection of supernatural tales by China's most powerful literary official. Ji Yun deliberately wrote in a classical, sparse style as a counterpoint to Pu Songling's ornate Liaozhai. Contains ~1,200 stories of wit, moral commentary, and ghost stories.

title_en: Legendary Tale of the Green Wilds
description: Ranked alongside Honglou Meng and Rulin Waishi as a great mid-Qing novel. Blends Daoist cultivation, political intrigue, and romance during the Ming Jiajing era.

title_en: An Old Rustic's Idle Talk
description: The longest pre-modern Chinese novel at 154 chapters. Follows scholar Wen Suchen through examinations, romances, and military campaigns in an encyclopedic narrative.

title_en: Lamp at the Crossroads
description: A major Qing educational novel about a scholar's son squandering his inheritance. Only rediscovered in the 20th century; no complete English translation exists.

title_en: Pacifying the Bandits
description: Anti-Water Margin sequel where the Liangshan outlaws are portrayed as villains. Lu Xun praised its literary quality despite its reactionary ideology.

title_en: Three Heroes and Five Gallants
description: The foundational Chinese martial-arts and detective novel combining Judge Bao courtroom drama with wuxia heroics. Source for countless later adaptations.

title_en: A Flower in a Sea of Sin
description: A major roman a clef of late Qing diplomacy, politics, and scandal. Only 5 chapters translated into English (1982). One of the four great novels of the late Qing.

title_en: Complete Tale of the Flying Dragon
description: Historical novel about the founding of the Song dynasty by Zhao Kuangyin (Emperor Taizu). A classic of dynastic-founding fiction.

title_en: Unofficial History of the Female Immortals
description: Fantastical novel set during the Yongle Emperor's usurpation, blending historical events with Daoist supernatural elements and female warrior protagonists.

title_en: Model Words to Shape the World
description: A late Ming vernacular story collection only rediscovered in Korea in 1992. Forty stories of moral exemplars, remarkably well-preserved.

title_en: New Records of Yu Chu
description: Anthology of the finest literary Chinese tales from the late Ming and early Qing, curated by one of the period's foremost literary arbiters.

title_en: What Canon?
description: The first novel written in Wu dialect (Shanghainese). A satirical ghost-world picaresque championed by Lu Xun and Hu Shi during the New Culture Movement.

title_en: Record of the Millet Dream
description: Detailed record of life in Southern Song Hangzhou modeled on the Dongjing Menghua Lu. Documents markets, crafts, festivals, and urban culture before the Mongol conquest.

title_en: Past Events of Wulin
description: Zhou Mi's nostalgic record of Southern Song Hangzhou's court ceremonies, festivals, entertainments, and daily life before the Mongol conquest.

title_en: Rustic Words from East of Qi
description: Zhou Mi's politically revealing biji covering Southern Song court politics, the Zhu Xi scandal, painting connoisseurship, and other historical anecdotes.

title_en: Jade Dew from the Crane Forest
description: Song dynasty biji covering poetry criticism, historical anecdotes, philosophical discussions, and political commentary.

title_en: Records Heard by the Si River
description: Private notes by the great historian Sima Guang recording political events and anecdotes from the Northern Song that did not make it into the Zizhi Tongjian.

title_en: Gathered Words of the Tang
description: The most detailed source on Tang dynasty civil service examinations, poetry culture, and the social world of examination candidates.

title_en: Trivial Tales from North of the Dreams
description: Important biji covering late Tang through Five Dynasties anecdotes, politics, and literary culture across three decades of compilation.

title_en: Miscellaneous Records of the Western Capital
description: One of the earliest Chinese short story collections, recording court life, customs, and legends of the Western Han capital Chang'an. 129 stories.

title_en: Records by the Autumn Lamp on Rainy Nights
description: Late Qing collection of classical tales in the tradition of Liaozhai, noted for its literary polish and tragic love stories.

title_en: Five Assorted Offerings
description: Massive encyclopedic biji covering astronomy, geography, natural history, customs, and curiosities. Contains the earliest known mention of rock-paper-scissors.

title_en: Records of Things Gleaned
description: Important early collection of myths, legends, and supernatural tales spanning from mythological antiquity to the Jin dynasty. Includes descriptions of Penglai and Kunlun.

title_en: Searching for West Lake in Dreams
description: Zhang Dai's lyrical guide to West Lake in Hangzhou, written decades after the Ming collapse. 72 essays organized by geographic route. Only partial translations exist in anthologies.

title_en: The Wisdom Sack
description: Massive anthology of 1,238 stories of stratagems and wit from Chinese history, organized by type of wisdom. Feng Menglong's most scholarly compilation.

title_en: History of Love
description: The largest anthology of love stories in Chinese literature, with 870+ stories drawn from official histories, biji, and fiction. Organized into 24 categories of love and passion.

title_en: Studies at Leisure by the Staircase
description: Major work of Qing evidential scholarship investigating origins of customs, institutions, and historical claims. Zhao Yi was one of the three leading historians of the Qian-Jia era.

title_en: Biographies of Talented Men of the Tang
description: The most important source for biographies of Tang dynasty poets. Contains entries for 398 poets arranged by quality and era.

title_en: Survey of Jokes Past and Present
description: Curated anthology of witticisms and satirical anecdotes from Chinese history, organized into 36 categories. Companion volume to Zhinang and Qingshi.

title_en: The Night Ferry
description: A witty encyclopedic compendium covering 20 categories from astronomy to botany with 4,000+ entries, meant as conversational reference for educated travelers on night boats.

title_en: Seven Swords and Thirteen Heroes
description: One of the most popular late Qing martial arts novels, set during the Zhengde reign. Features a band of righteous swordsmen suppressing a princely rebellion.

title_en: Random Records from the Whistling Pavilion
description: Written by a Qing imperial prince (Aisin Gioro clan), this biji offers insider accounts of Qing court politics, Manchu customs, and Bannerman life unavailable from any other source.
